item.title: SCSS and Bower
item.description:
Today we went through SCSS/Sass, asset packs, and bower. Feels a bit like a haze, I honestly can barely remember what we learned today. SCSS I understand, it’s a CSS simplifier that compiles scss into css. I think I understand bower, it’s like a package manager for front end stuff. Not sure I understand assetpack, I think it’s a compiler for everything, but I’m not sure where bower ends and asset pack begins or even where SCSS fits into it. A bit of a weird day, like it all kind of melds into one, and I can see how to use it but not how the pieces of the puzzle are shaped and how they fit together.

Homework is ramping up for me. I’ve hit the point where I’m forgoing functionality or style to finish everything I want to finish (though tbh I’m aiming above the minimum spec of the homework). I’m still managing to finish what my priorities are, but I’m no longer having the time to really make stuff fantastic. A lot of it I feel is muscle work rather than brain work, so by the time you hit the brain work, you’ve spent a lot of time tackling other muscle-work fine-touch kind of things, so you’re tired. I guess the goal is to make your stuff bug free and almost in muscle memory.

Overall I admit my full understanding of how this all works and how to type it blind etc etc is still pretty hazy, so I hope over time I’ll get more practice and be able to type all of this stuff without having to fully rely on copying and pasting code that had previously worked and that we had done before. Oh well.

For homework we had to do Carmen Sandiago via SQL queries. Which I was fairly happy to get as homework, because I knew I needed practice with it, but I strapped myself in to struggle with it. And struggle I did. Then near the end, came a watershed moment where I saw JOIN’s face clearly, and understood what it did. item.title: Subway homework
item.description:
We started with ruby today, and I managed to get up to go the the gym. Hurrah. Ruby feels a little bit foreign to me, I guess I’m a little less ‘human’ now? I find the brackets and the clear notation of javascript a little comforting, but ruby’s just another language and I definitely agree the error handling for ruby feels so much more elegant and useful.

The other thing we learnt was Matz Is Nice And So We Are Nice, or MINASWAN, which amuses me. Since Matz is JP, I’m sure it was made with the idea that we are all special swans, since ‘mina’ is ‘everyone’ in jp. Also I learnt he’s Mormon. So this all makes sense to me. JP is an unreasonably polite culture, and the Church of the Latter Day Saints are too.

Then we learned about arrays and objects and symbols in Ruby, made a calculator, then homework.

Homework was really interesting to me, since the most elegant and novel solution isn’t the best solution. The elegant and novel solution involves assigning values based on a theoretical zero point. The normal solution just uses normal distance indexes. While both work, the elegant and novel solution is really short,but requires a little work to assign values. The other requires a lot more code, but ends up being scalable and adjustable. Kinda interesting. I guess it takes more code to be stable, but less code to be pretty.

In the end I wrote 180 lines. And most of it was because of stability and user experience. I can’t really tell how elegant my solution is, because of it… but it does work really smoothly.

item.title: Midway through second project
item.description:
I’m writing this on Sat morning, as a sort of update on what I achieved yesterday and as a sort of work-in-progress review of the things I’m going to need to do today as well.

Yesterday I finished generating collision functions on my game, and made it such that the player can’t move outside of the play field. One major problem with collision is that it’s an all-or-nothing response, and that one collision quickly becomes 4-6 collisions because it detects at each frame. Therefore if I make the player lose a life on every detected collision, a player can lose 5-7 lives on a single move through a bullet. To fix this I added collision thresholds, where a player must accumulate 2-3 collisions to be considered hit, and lose a life. This fixed my problem, until I realised that it was still happening where players would now lose 2-3 lives on one move through a bullet, which is reduced but still not ideal. I thus added a clause where if a player took damage, her collision counter would reset to a larger value than the base, such that she would have to have more collisions after a life loss to trigger a 2nd life loss.

I thought I fixed it there, but then someone pointed out that damage thresholds seemed to be cumulative, where you would be fairly safe after taking the first hit of damage, and have to accumulate collisions to take life damage. I then added two more functions to fix this— basically pushing the player-state towards a base collision threshold value, so that after taking damage the threshold returns to normal after some time, and that if you do make a minor collision that doesn’t reach damage threshold, playing safe causes your damage threshold to return to normal values.

The other major breakthroughs I had yesterday were enemy generation and enemy animation. Based on the position and size of the play area, I can generate enemies that move directly up or down. One problem that stumped me, and now I’m not sure why, is that I couldn’t figure out how to create an array that stored all the enemies I created. For some reason I was convinced it was really difficult and I’d have to use prototypical inheritance and constructor functions, and create objects within objects with unique names, and my collision detection would have to know all these names and somehow have them etc etc etc etc. While all those statements -could- be true, talking with one of the TAs made me realise… I can just use an index as an identifier, and use an array to store my enemies. At this point the problem disappeared and I managed to get my enemy generation working.

The length and complexity of my code is getting to the point where I think I should have created object modules to handle things and separate a whole bunch of things. For example I think my collision calculations should be just one section, my enemy generation another section, and potentially 2-3 more sections. It’s not going to hinder my project, but I really feel like it should be organised a bit better. It’s rather messy right now.

Now things to do:

Important things- Add a game over function, design the loss. Add a game success function, design the success. Add levels (perhaps design difficulty?) Game start function

Added functionality- Generate random sizes of enemies Generate/remove player functions- allowing pauses between stages.

Fun- second screen. hidden scores for second screen. animation for title etc. story.

item.title: Start of first project
item.description:
It’s basically the start of our projects, and I discovered late last night that one of the alumni made Duck Hunt. Not to be outdone, I decided to create dual element game in the vein of The World Ends With You, a dual screen game. Totally stoked to do it… until I actually had to do it. Without using libraries and stuff, I’m finding myself looking up online for a whole bunch of solutions to a whole bunch of problems.

First an outline of the game: 2 screens.

The main screen is a ‘bullet hell’ type game, where you use the arrow keys to move a box around the screen to avoid bullets that fly at you.

The second screen is a clicking type game, where you click the right coloured things or whatever sort of clicking mouse mini game I can think of, maybe a hover game. Success in this game gives positive feedback to the other game, maybe via removing enemies, or dropping extra health for the player to collect.

As a concept, and with other libraries and tools, it doesn’t seem terribly hard, since a lot of people make these kinds of games, but in raw javascript this has become some form of herculean task, where I’m thinking about the math of all the events and what I need to do, and at the same time trying to think of how javascript needs to work to do it. I’ll outline what problems I’ve met, and what I’ve solved.

Firstly I had to figure out how to make my player move. I’ve done that. Then I had to figure out how to make collision detect. I’ve done that.

The next problem is how to make collision stop things. For example I need to stop my player from flying out of the play area.

I’m getting a headache.

item.description:
Friday rolled round, a really chill day today actually. Went through a 3rd version of a calculator, this time with numbered buttons that are the interface for input, as opposed to one with multiple input fields and operations. Kinda cool, I neglected the idea of simply changing the data in the DOM HTML as a form of storage until then.

On reflection, covered a lot of things this week. I wouldn’t be able to do what I can do now a week ago. It’s a lot of content, and they highlighted the amount of content we went through. I’m still not super challenged yet, but it’s been kinda fun challenging myself and reaching further than I probably should.

On Friday, we wrapped up early, and went to the pub after reviewing the week, and I pretty much was recommended not to start on my homework until Saturday, so get a good sleep and just start fresh. I admit I pretty much disregarded that advice, and got my homework to a submittable state on Friday night after about an hour and a half.

That being said, I did probably spend about 4-5 more hours on it, trying to add a lot more functionality, and playing around with the most elegant solutions to the code. In the end, I added a game win counter, added a function that basically stores each game played at the bottom of the screen, and finally programmed the computer to play against you. Since it’s tic-tac-toe, I basically programmed it to win or draw, since there is an optimal hand in tic-tac-toe. I also learned some tricks to style it. Actually the process of figuring how to program the computer to play tic-tac-toe, and how to style it, was really interesting and useful, and I thus probably spent way too much time on it that I should have.

I also learned that sleeping on a problem really helps you get a solution. I was having a problem figuring out how to get the script to identify moves that would allow it to win, and I slept on the problem. And when I woke, I had the solution.

Oh well, let’s see how the next week goes.

item.title: Javascript with pages
item.description:
Today we did functions, and DOM, and thus making our javascript interact with webpages. Quite challenging, I developed a headache that still hasn’t gone away and it’s 2am. I suspect I’m overthinking a lot of things, and tracking a lot of things I don’t need to track in my head and that’s what’s giving me the headache. It feels like the same kind of headache when I start planning too far ahead than what is comfortable for me in games like Go or even Spacechem (a puzzle game) some times. Either that or it’s just staring at the screen too much and the light is giving me it.

I really like the idea of keeping my code dry, and using a lot of functions to simplify a lot of the code that you use. I really like tidy looking code that I can easily interpret, otherwise it just annoys me. Simple is beautiful, what can I say.

item.title: Javascript Prompt Calculator Homework
item.description:
I realise I have a somewhat irreverent description of my time in WDI in GA. To clarify, I still think about the course a lot, it’s just that my learning is fairly directed and easy to describe, so it comes out as succinct comments. The other small bits about the day just amuse me, but are a lot harder for me to describe. I record the day’s progress by a series of notes, and a vast majority of them aren’t strictly work related.

So my goal in sitting today, after sitting next to the air conditioner that blew cold air at me most of the day on Tuesday, was to sit on the left near the window. Become Dayman, fighter of the Nightman, champion of the sun. I must say, I really like the sides for the extra space to put your bag and water and stuff. And the sunny side is more pleasant, but doesn’t have as good a view on the board, since the board is on the right and our instructor, Alex, is right handed.

I also decided to travel much further for food for lunch, all the way to the Japanese Kitchen, which Cat suggested. I had the Korean Fried Chicken donburi for 6 pds, and it was pretty big, and really tasty. I realise I’m spending a lot on food for a person on course. I’ll cut down as time rolls on, but food is a fairly personal thing, and culturally and personally, I value eating. I don’t spend much on other things, but I definitely love eating- and in general I eat a lot.

Standard scrum, didn’t drop the duck, and I presented my website. Fairly happy with it, it wasn’t as bad as I thought it really was, but I’d really like to fix a lot of it to be neater in my head. It’s probably never-ending, refining your website until you’re completely happy with it, but the website is certainly functional. It’s pointed out I should get in the habit of using tags like &lta> and &ltnav> and things like that to at least denote what things are meant to be and so on.

After which we went through positioning, floating, and clearing in CSS, a topic which I really feel is just a matter of practice, since the more sites you build, the more familiar you’re going to end up with how the positioning all works. As it is, it really feels like the differences between inline and inline float, seem rather unclear, but I guess in time they will seem more obvious.

Had an outcomes talk, about finding a job, the game-plan kinda job. I always get a little nervous about these things, because pitching at the right level always feels a little challenging. Am I being overconfident and cocky? Am I underselling the things I can do? Especially when my depth of technical knowledge and industry knowledge isn’t really there, I always get nervous about these outcome talks.

Then came an intro to javascript, and command flows, and in the afternoon we did paired programming of a basic game using basic javascript command flows, ‘if’s, ‘else’s, ‘while’s, ‘for’s and ‘switch’es. Also returning results using alerts and console.logs. I’d done quite a bit of it before so it all felt fairly natural, as did the homework of making a javascript prompt driven calculator. Working with Faduma was fairly easy, but for sure I found it difficult explaining exactly the kind of game that I wanted to create in concrete terms that would help code. The problem I suspect is that I’m building the structure of the code as I describe what I want, which ends up being too specific for a guideline, and not specific enough to actually be code. While this makes the coding decisions easier for me, it did mean that when Faduma was coding, how or what to code isn’t fully clear. I somewhat felt like I was mostly leading her, so I feel a little bad about it, but I honestly hope she got something out of it.

I must admit, both my projects today were very entertaining for me to build, and probably very self indulgent. The game Faduma and I built was a simulation of Monty Python’s Bridge of Doom skit in The Quest for The Holy Grail, which asks 3 questions and kills knights if you answer it badly. She suggested a quiz, and off the cuff that was the first game-like quiz that came to my mind. Following on the theme, I named the calculator we made for homework ‘The Mathemagician’. I also added a lot of attitude to the prompts, and the calculator constantly insults you while doing the operations. A very user-unfriendly calculator. I enjoyed it, but I would not recommend actually using it for anything but your own amusement a few times. Probably a low Metacritic Score. Would not see on Steam Greenlight.

This is a really long blog post, mostly because I finished the work really quickly and painlessly today, so there’s not much mental fatigue. The posts’ll probably thin out over time.

item.title: Instagram Homework Day
item.description:
Today I learnt that Alex really likes to use analogies. While I personally drift off slightly when the tea and biscuits, ingredients and cooking analogies are employed, it’s probably a good way to normalise otherwise esoteric ideas.

We went through using git, github, html and css, and now it’s just a matter of getting familiar and using it a lot. One thing’s for sure, I anticipate commitment problems. It seems a little counter intuitive to save and then double save every now and then via committing. Only one thing to do- git gud.

Called my friend to cancel a dinner with his parents at Lurra, which evidently is a meat place because when I got home my significant other had brought me a bone with some meat on it. Good stuff.

Got stuck in with the homework- copying a webpage from a png. Most people stayed back to around 8.30, I left around 9.00 and on the way back realised I wanted to tweak a little bit of the code, so I did. My significant other also pointed out that wayback machine online caches the old webpages that we were assigned to copy. I took a look at the bits I couldn’t figure out after I decided I was done with the homework to confirm some of my suspicions. Maybe I’ll correct it to be more in-line with the original website eventually, but as far as homework goes, I probably should just leave it as I did it, and not ‘cheat’, and just learn about how they actually did it another time.

item.title: First Day
item.description:
WDI started, and I was told it would be useful to record the things I did, maybe the thoughts I had, and oh the place I’ll go. So I guess I’ll start with where I’ve begun.

I’ve started a Web Development Intensive course at General Assembly, where I should be learning how to use javascript, java libraries, and ruby and its associated libraries. My previous experience is mostly copy pasting with mild modifications scripts for Excel or HTML and CSS back from 2004. While I’d done some Codeacademy javascript before the course, and the precourse javascript work, I’d never really done any of the hard stuff, or had anything to really build with the coding languages that I was taught.

So today I installed a bunch of stuff on a MacBook which I’ve borrowed from a good friend for the course, learned how to fold a great paper aeroplane, and had a pint at a pub.

Fairly productive first day, except for the installing- that was incredibly dry.
